gw.api.web

Class RequestVar<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • gw.api.web.RequestVar<T>

  • public class RequestVar<T>
extends java.lang.Object
    The value assigned to an instance of this class is stored in the HttpRequest that is currently in scope, as tracked by the Guidewire platform. In some execution contexts, such as inside a batch process, a request is not available and accessing an instance of this class will result in an IllegalStateException. Use isRequestAvailable() to detect that situation.

    See below for a typical usage of a RequestVar. Access to the variable is encapsulated in the MyClass.MyRequestVar static property for ease of use.

    The RequestVar instance contains the key that is used to set and lookup the value of the variable in the HttpRequest. You cannot control which key is used, and so you must provide static access to the same RequestVar to access its value from different parts of the application. Note that although the property is static, that's only to hold the RequestVar and its key. Getting and setting the value will be done in the current HttpRequest, and so will be unique to each UI transaction. 

       // Assign a value to the request variable
   // This can be done early in the request, such as in a PCF page
   MyClass.MyRequestVar = "hello"

   // Access the request variable
   // This could be done later, such as in rules or IPreUpdateHandler
   print( MyClass.MyRequestVar )

   class MyClass {
     static var _varStoredInRequest = new RequestVar()

     static property get MyRequestVar() : String {
       if ( _varStoredInRequest.RequestAvailable ) {
         return _varStoredInRequest.get()
       } else {
         return null
       }
     }
     static property set MyRequestVar( value: String ) {
       if ( _varStoredInRequest.RequestAvailable ) {
         _varStoredInRequest.set( value )
       }
     }
   }

      • isRequestAvailable

        public boolean isRequestAvailable()
        Returns True if it is safe to call get() and set(). Otherwise, those methods will throw an exception.

        Tests if there is an HTTP request in context. The absence of a request indicates there is nowhere to store the value of this variable. Sometimes it's useful to test for the request if it's possible to execute the enclosing code block in an environment that may not run within a request or session. For instance, batch processes execute independent of a request.

        Returns:
        True if an HTTP request is currently in context, as tracked by the Guidewire platform. Otherwise false.
